figures.description: Indifference‑curve diagram for Question 5. Horizontal axis: Good X (1,2,3,4 units). Vertical axis: Good Y (0–18). A downward‑sloping, convex curve shows combinations of X and Y. Point S corresponds to X=1, Y≈18; point T corresponds to X=3, Y≈9. The marginal rate of substitution (MRS) of X for Y from S to T equals the change in Y divided by the change in X.

Pie chart for Question 4. The circle is divided into three segments: Children 40%, Women 35%, Men 25%. Candidates must convert the children’s percentage to angle in degrees: \(0.40 \times 360^\circ = 144^\circ\).

Two production‑possibility diagrams for Question 23. Each is a straight‑line frontier between cocoa (vertical axis, tonnes) and cotton (horizontal axis, tonnes). Ghana: maximum cocoa 20 tonnes with 0 cotton, or maximum cotton 5 tonnes with 0 cocoa. Nigeria: also 20 tonnes of cocoa or 5 tonnes of cotton. The opportunity cost of 1 unit of cotton in terms of cocoa is \(20/5 = 4\) tonnes of cocoa in each country.

Demand–supply diagram for Question 34. Vertical axis: price P; horizontal axis: quantity Q. Downward‑sloping demand curve D and upward‑sloping supply curve S intersect at an equilibrium price below ₦60. At price ₦60 (horizontal line), quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied, creating excess demand equal to the horizontal distance between D and S at ₦60 (e.g. between 100 and 200 units).

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: If goods P and Q are purchased by a consumer, a fall in the price of P with the price of Q unchanged will cause the budget line to

options.text: rotate outwards away from the origin

questions.explanation: A fall in the price of P (with income and price of Q constant) makes P relatively cheaper, so the budget line **pivots outwards along the P‑axis**.

questions.question: One of the reasons for an exceptional demand curve is the

options.text: change in the price of the commodity
expectation of a future change in price

questions.explanation: If consumers expect **future price increases**, they may buy more at higher current prices, giving an upward‑sloping (exceptional) demand curve.

questions.question: The elasticity of supply of perishable goods is
questions.explanation: Because perishable goods cannot be stored, supply is **relatively inelastic** in the short run.

questions.question: In the pie chart (figure Econ2002_PieChart_Children), the percentage for children is 40%. The corresponding angle in degrees is
questions.explanation: Central angle = \(0.40 \times 360^\circ = 144^\circ\).

questions.question: In the indifference diagram (figure Econ2002_MRS_Diagram), what is the marginal rate of substitution (MRS) of X for Y for a movement from S to T?
questions.explanation: Approximate MRS = \(\frac{\Delta Y}{\Delta X} = \frac{18 - 9}{3 - 1} = 9/2 = 4.5\). The precise figures on the scan are unclear, so no option can be chosen with certainty.

questions.question: A scientific approach in economic analysis entails
questions.explanation: Economists use **both inductive (from data) and deductive (from theory)** methods.

questions.question: In a centrally planned economy, the economic problem of deciding what to produce is dependent on
questions.explanation: In such economies the **state (central authority)** decides output.

questions.question: A shift in the supply curve indicates that a different quantity will be supplied at each possible price because

options.text: consumers are willing to pay higher prices
other factors than price have changed

questions.explanation: Supply curve shifts occur when **non‑price determinants of supply** change.

questions.question: The demand for factors of production is an example of
questions.explanation: Factors are demanded **because of what they help produce**, so their demand is derived.

questions.question: A student has N30 with which to buy a ruler costing N18 and an exercise book costing N25. If he buys the exercise book, his opportunity cost is
questions.explanation: The foregone alternative is the **ruler**.

questions.question: Import substitution aims at

options.text: substituting agricultural products with industrial ones

questions.explanation: By producing domestically what was formerly imported, import substitution **improves the balance of payments** and industrial base.

questions.question: Some of the key indicators of underdevelopment in a country are

options.text: poverty, low level of literacy and low income
poverty, low income and low unemployment level
poverty, high level of literacy and low income
low level of literacy, low income and poverty

questions.explanation: Underdevelopment is marked by **widespread poverty, low literacy and low incomes**.

questions.question: ECOWAS has taken a giant step towards economic integration by

options.text: introducing a common currency for travellers
presenting a united front against foreign economic exploiters
holding frequent meetings at various state capitals
increasing economic stability among member states

questions.explanation: ECOWAS introduced the **ECOWAS Traveller’s Cheque and regional currencies** to promote integration.

questions.question: One of the major factors militating against industrialization in Nigeria is the

options.text: failure to get foreign partners and supporters

questions.explanation: Poor **infrastructure** (power, roads, port facilities) severely constrains industrialization.

questions.question: The types, sources and uses of government income are mainly concerned with
questions.explanation: **Public finance** examines government revenue, expenditure and debt.

questions.question: The present privatization policy in Nigeria is aimed at

options.text: reducing the prices of goods and services

questions.explanation: Privatization is intended to **improve efficiency** and reduce government burden.

questions.question: One of the roles of the NNPC in the production and refining of crude oil is to

options.text: secure maximum government revenue and regulate price
protect the local operators in the petroleum industry
prevent the smuggling of petroleum products
satisfy the domestic consumption of petroleum products

questions.explanation: NNPC coordinates the oil sector to **maximize revenue** for government and help regulate prices.

questions.question: One way of correcting the balance‑of‑payments problem of a country is to
questions.explanation: Devaluation makes exports cheaper and imports dearer, improving the **current‑account balance**.

questions.question: One of the problems arising from the localization of industries is
questions.explanation: If a localized industry declines, the region may suffer **structural unemployment**.

questions.question: The major purpose of the African Development Bank is to

options.text: educate peasant farmers in new techniques
provide loans for development banks in distress

questions.explanation: AfDB’s core mandate is to finance **development projects**, especially infrastructure.

questions.question: As a country gets more developed, the percentage of labour engaged in agriculture tends to
questions.explanation: With development, labour moves from **agriculture to industry and services**, so its share falls.

questions.question: A deficit budget can be used to

options.text: starve the economy of funds for economic development
stimulate recovery from trade depression and provide measures to remedy balance‑of‑payments problems

questions.explanation: Deficit spending is a **counter‑cyclical tool** to stimulate recovery and correct external imbalances.

questions.question: In the cocoa–cotton diagrams (figure Econ2002_CottonCocoa_PPF), what is the opportunity cost of a unit of cotton in terms of cocoa?
questions.explanation: From each PPF, \(20\) tonnes cocoa trade off against \(5\) tonnes cotton, so **1 tonne cotton = 4 tonnes cocoa** in both countries.

questions.question: External finance for a limited‑liability company is mainly sourced through
questions.explanation: Major sources of **external finance** are **loans** from banks and other lenders.

questions.question: One of the major criticisms of the 1962 National Development Plan was that

options.text: its execution was based on foreign‑sourced financial resources
it failed to incorporate lessons from earlier plans
planned expenditure was based too heavily on expected earnings from crude oil
it came too quickly after the country’s independence

questions.explanation: The plan relied heavily on **foreign aid and loans**, making it vulnerable.

questions.question: Which of the following yields more revenue to Nigeria?
questions.explanation: **VAT** is a major and growing source of federal revenue.

questions.question: In the short run a firm’s marginal‑cost curve above the point of shut‑down is its
questions.explanation: For a competitive firm, **supply curve = MC curve above min AVC**.

questions.question: The benefits that accrue to a firm as a result of an improvement in the industry it belongs to are called
questions.explanation: These are **external economies of scale**.

questions.question: As a firm increases its output, the average fixed cost
questions.explanation: AFC = TFC/Q; as Q rises, **AFC falls continuously**.

questions.question: The economic policy of deregulation is aimed at encouraging
questions.explanation: Deregulation reduces controls to foster **competition**.

questions.question: The effect of an increase in demand for a commodity accompanied by a decrease in supply will be to

options.text: decrease the equilibrium quantity and affect the price in an indeterminate way
raise the price of the commodity and affect the quantity in an indeterminate way
lower its price while affecting the equilibrium quantity in an indeterminate way
raise its price as well as the equilibrium quantity

questions.explanation: Higher demand and lower supply both push **price up**; effect on quantity depends on relative shifts (indeterminate).

questions.question: Under conditions of perfect competition a firm’s supply curve is determined by its
questions.explanation: Again, supply is the **MC curve above minimum AVC**.

questions.question: The short‑run equilibrium output for a monopolist is determined by the

options.text: intersection of the marginal‑cost and marginal‑revenue curves
highest point on the total‑revenue curve
intersection of the average‑revenue and average‑cost curves
minimum point on the average‑cost curve

questions.explanation: Profit maximization: **MC = MR**.

questions.question: In the demand–supply diagram (figure Econ2002_ExcessDemand_Diagram), what is the excess demand at the price of N60?
questions.explanation: At P=60, Qd=200 and Qs=100, so excess demand = \(Q_d - Q_s = 100\). (Values inferred from labels around 100 and 200 in the diagram.)

questions.question: The equilibrium wage in an economy is determined by the
questions.explanation: In a labour market, wage is set where **labour demand equals supply**.

questions.question: If the growth rate of available resources continuously outpaces that of the population, a country will eventually experience
questions.explanation: Resources growing faster than population implies **under‑population** relative to capacity.

questions.question: The middlemen in the chain of distribution are
questions.explanation: **Wholesalers and retailers** stand between producers and final consumers.

questions.question: The Malthusian theory of population growth is often said to be
questions.explanation: Malthus predicted that population would outstrip food supply, leading to famine; this is **pessimistic**.

questions.question: Improved labour efficiency can be measured by
questions.explanation: Efficiency rises when each unit of input produces **more output**, i.e. higher output/input ratio.

questions.question: National income estimates can be used to

options.text: compare a country’s growth rate with that of another over time
differentiate between the rich and poor in a country
project the level of a country’s economic development

questions.explanation: NI statistics facilitate **international and inter‑temporal comparisons of growth**.

questions.question: Creeping inflation implies that there is a

options.text: rapid but not permanent increase in the general price level
gentle but not permanent increase in the general price level
rapid and persistent increase in the general price level
gentle and persistent increase in the general price level

questions.explanation: **Creeping inflation** is slow and steady.

questions.question: In a closed economy, the marginal propensity to consume is 0.6 and the average propensity to consume is 0.8. The value of the multiplier is
questions.explanation: Investment multiplier \(k = 1/(1-MPC) = 1/(1-0.6) = 1/0.4 = 2.5\). (Closest option is 2.5; some scans show 2.4, but mathematically it is **2.5**.)

questions.question: Excess‑demand inflation can be controlled through
questions.explanation: **Reducing government spending or raising taxes** (contractionary fiscal policy) lowers aggregate demand.

questions.question: The primary objective of the NDIC is to

options.text: provide regulations guiding the finance houses
give protection to banks against fraud
give protection to the CBN against fraud

questions.explanation: The Nigerian Deposit Insurance Corporation protects **depositors’ funds** in case of bank failure.

questions.question: Money may not be accepted as a store of value if
questions.explanation: Unstable purchasing power undermines money’s role as a **store of value**.

questions.question: Liquidity preference refers to the

options.text: wish to hold more funds for precautionary purposes
need to increase the money supply to lower interest rate
demand to hold money as assets rather than as stocks
need to borrow money for short periods to meet temporary crises

questions.explanation: Liquidity preference is the **desire to hold wealth as money** for transactions and precaution.

questions.question: If the country’s GNP in the current year is N65 billion and the GNP deflator is 130, the real GNP is
questions.explanation: Real GNP = \(\frac{\text{nominal}}{\text{deflator}/100} = \frac{65}{1.3} ≈ 50\). (Options don’t match; possibly printed differently in original paper.)

questions.question: Insurance companies invest mainly in instruments traded on the
questions.explanation: Insurers invest long‑term funds in **capital‑market instruments** (bonds, equities).

questions.question: The solution to the problem of double coincidence of wants requires a buyer and a seller whose demands are precisely
questions.explanation: In barter, double coincidence requires **complementary wants**—each wants what the other offers.

questions.question: The stock exchange is a market for the buying and selling of
questions.explanation: A stock exchange is primarily a **secondary market for existing securities**.
